DIRECTOR: Dan Ireland



CAST: Vincent D'Onofrio, RenÃƒÂ©e Zellweger, Ann Wedgeworth, Harve Presnell, Benjamin Mouton, ...


PLOT:
-----------
This is a true love story of the largely platonic three-year romance between a prim Texas school teacher and the misanthropic, half-crazy writer of sword and sorcery stories, Robert E. Howard. Beginning in 1933 and done in a low key realistic style that remains close to that of the memoirs of Novalyne Price, the teacher, it is a painful yet strong testament to the power of a woman's love. Though an educator, Price aspires to become a writer herself. Howard was always an odd duck; though fully grown, he lives with his parents and shouts out his stories as he writes them on his typewriter. Most of the townsfolk regard him as a little touched, but Price is intrigued with the work of Howard, the creator of such sexy, violent tales as "Conan the Barbarian," "Red Sonja," and "Solomon Kane," and so engineers a meeting with him. She finds him a fascinating, volatile character. The two begin to date and spend many hours driving around Texas in his convertible. The paradoxically egotistical and insecure Howard does most of the talking, bragging about his ability to create while putting down those writers who try to chronicle real life. Soon Price and Howard become emotionally and intellectually intimate. Howard is moody and often follows periods of intense communication with times of withdrawal and silence. He accepts the things Price freely gives, but seems unwilling or unable to compromise himself or his artistic visions and give much in return.
